Hey,
I'm Freddy Liu

Love to find and solve problems. Having innovative, critical, and comprehensive thinking. Eager to pick up new stuffs.

I was a professional civil engineer previously and fully dive into Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and Web Development.

I am endlessly curious about how machine finds specific patterns or features in existing data, and how these patterns and features generate predictions for certain problems. This curiosity brings me into the world of Machine Learning and feeling excited diging new things.

However I find a need for human and computer interaction when data and model need visualization. That makes the predicted model really presents its value. This demend leads me into picking up Web Development skills and find more passion working with them.

Active, responsible, and team working are characteristics that describles me. Full of diversities and willing to try new things are living codes to my lifestyle as well. Other than working, I love volleyballs, badminton, musics, playing in a band, traveling and cooking. All of them build me up and make me not afraid of difficulties, but to overcome with creative and intuitive opinions.

If you've been this far, please leave me a message. I'd love to hear your voice.

Dog Breed Classifier

View .ipynb

Tools:

  • - Tensorflow
  • - Tensorflow Hub
  • - Transfer Learning
  • - TensorBoard
  • - Mobilenet V2

Main Goal: Take an image of dog and classify what breed it is.

Dataset Description

This dataset is from Kaggle dog breed identification competition. https://www.kaggle.com/c/dog-breed-identification/data
It contains 10,000 images from 120 breeds of dogs in training set, and another 10,000 images in test set we need to predict.

Evalutaion

Give the predicted label from test set and evaluate through Kaggle competition. The evaluation of this competition is Multi Class Log Loss.

Result

We want to use Tranfer Learning. Use a pre-trained model built from others and feed our taining data in order to get a nice and appropriate result. We choose Mobilenet V2 with image size of 224 x 224 pixels, and also create 2 callback functions. One is TensorBoard, which allow us to catch up each accuracy and loss after training is done. Another one is EarlyStopping, which is to prevent overfitting by stopping training process if evaluation metrics stops improving.
After taining finished and upload the predicted result, the final metrics goes to about 0.3, which still needs a lot of improvement.

Where to go from here

We can do some image augmentation before training to prevent overfitting and generates a better model predicting result such as ImageDataGenerator, or try other CNN models for better results.

Back

Back

Smart Brain

View Source Code

Tools:

  • - Front-End: React.js
  • - Back-End: Node.js + Express.js
  • - Database: PostgreSQL

Introduction

This website mainly takes an image and detect faces in the image. It can store users information in database and record how many times a user has played for the face recognition App. The Face Recognition API is from Clarifai (https://www.clarifai.com/models/face-detection). We take the third party API and connect to my project.

Work along the project

This is my first React App project. An end-to-end practice for ajax syntax, redux use, and user interface creation. Most important in this project, a sign-in and register page is used in it. For the user information, some important issue should be considered:

  • - User ID and password is securely pass from Front-End to Back-End.
  • - The third party API key should hide from public

We use bcrypt-nodejs to encrypt password and pass to Back-End and database. Then take the API request in Back-End to avoid display API key in Front-End.

Where to go from here

Actually this is just a simple use of React framework to demo simple functions like connecting third party API and store user ID and password in database. Lots of expansions can be implemented in this projects like React Hooks. Other React skills can go from here to get deeper understanding in order to utilize in future projects.

Google Stock Price Prediction

View .ipynb

Tools:

  • - Tensorflow
  • - Recurrent Neural Network (RNN), LSTM
  • - NumPy
  • - Pandas
  • - Matplotlib

Main Goal: To predict future google stock price base on pass stock price.

Dataset Description

This dataset is from Public Financial Website.
It recorded the Google stock price from Jan. 1st, 2012, to Dec. 31st, 2016. Every data is a daily stock price of that date.

Evalutaion

To predict the stock price from Jan. 1st, 2017 to Jan. 31st, 2017 and compare to real stock price.

Result

We only take one indicator (the past stock price value) for LSTM model training. For the imestep I've tried 20, 30, ... and falls into 60 in the end (There are 20 stock market days per month, so its like using data from 3 months ago for prediction) in order to get the trend. In the final Output plot we can see there is a time delay between predicted and real stock price, but it can catch familiar trend and also avoid overfitting.

Where to go from here

We can add other indicators such as stock price from other companies, stock purchase amount, etc. For future use, RNN models can be widely used in different topics, and it should be worthy to dive deeper.

Heart Disease Classification

View .ipynb

Tools:

  • - Scikit-Learn
  • - Logistic Regression, KNN, RandomForest
  • - K-fold Cross Validation
  • - GridSearchCV

Main Goal: To predict a preson whether has a heart disease or not based on clinical data.

Dataset Description

This dataset is from UCI Machine Learning Repository, https://archive.uci.edu/ml/datasets/heart+Disease
also a version on Kaggle. https://www.kaggle.com/ronitf/heart-disease-uci

Evalutaion

Calculate different metrics such as accuray, precision, recall, and F1 score. Compare different models and find the best solution.

Result

We try three different models: Logistic Regression, K-Nearest neighbors, and RandomForest. Train them with default settings, and then comes out the Logistic Regression model gets the highest accuracy. We use GridSearchCV for hyperparameter tuning. The final accuracy goes up to about 0.88, which does not meet a 90% accuracy. It still has some space for improvement.

Where to go from here

We can try different models such as XGBoost, or collect more data. Do more combinations with hyperparameters to improve our result.

Back

Bulldozer Price Prediction

View .ipynb

Tools:

  • - Scikit-Learn
  • - RandomForest
  • - K-fold Cross Validation
  • - RandomizedSearchCV

Main Goal: To predict future price of a bulldozer based on past similar data.

Dataset Description

This dataset is from Kaggle Bluebook for Bulldozers competition. https://www.kaggle.com/c/bluebook-for-bulldozers/data
There are three main datasets (Train.csv, Valid.csv, Test.csv). A data dictionary sheet is provided for all detailing of the features. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1aFjjRUQKvBnWVXxIbU8EnQIRiYa96QWj/edit#gid=810807387

Evalutaion

The evaluation metric for this competition is RMSLE (Root Mean Squared Log Error) between actual and predicted price. https://www.kaggle.com/c/bluebook-for-bulldozers/overview/evaluation

Result

First, there are some missing data in this dataset, so dealing with these missing values is a must. Fill in median values for numeric feature data, and category codes for category feature data. Also add binary column to indicate whether a sample has missing values.
After train with RandomForest model, we can get a metric RMSLE value of 0.25 for training set, and 0.29 for validation set. For test score show on Kaggle competition is 0.31, lies about top 60~70, still has much space for improvement.

Where to go from here

We can try different models such as XGBoost, or collect more data. Do more combinations with hyperparameters to improve our result.

Movie Recommendation

View .ipynb

Tools:

  • - PyTorch
  • - Restricted Boltzmann Machine (RBM)
  • - NumPy
  • - Pandas

Main Goal: Generate a movie recommendation system for users. Using the ratings that a specific user gives to a movie to predict ratings of other movies that the specific user didn't rate.

Dataset Description

This dataset is from grouplen.org. https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/
Contain all movies, users that give ratings to the movie, and the ratings. Also provide pre-split datasets for futre evaluation such as K-fold Cross Validation.

Evalutaion

We use average absolute distance for evaluation metric. Another possible metric is RMSE.

Result

Cause there is no similar framework for a boltzmann machine model, we create this from scratch and build up on top of PyTorch library. For the weight update algorithm we use Contrastive Divergence and Gibbs Sampling to update weights between visible nodes and hidden nodes. After training with weveral epochs, we then test with the model and get an accuray of 0.75, which is a good start but can be further improved.

Where to go from here

We build a simple RBM model for this project. We can add other attributes like hidden node units, K-sampling numbers, etc. Other than do user recommendation for movies we can use in different areas as well.
